message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: move What to Report to standalone file">
Vote requested: Should we move the "What to Report" section (lines 65-95 of the Standby Reader Profile) out of the Profile.md and into a standalone file?

The reasoning: Profile.md will be used as the prompt to generate/spawn the reader agent. If "What to Report" (including the per-essay questions, final prompts, and critical experiential checks) is part of that prompt, the reader will see all those questions BEFORE reading — which could bias their experience (e.g., knowing they'll be asked "What happened to your experience across the three examples?" for Essay 3 could prime them to watch for it).

Moving it to a standalone file means we can give the reader the profile (role, personality, reading instructions) at spawn, and then deliver the reporting questions AFTER they finish reading each piece — keeping the reading experience uncontaminated.

Vote YES to move "What to Report" to a standalone file, or NO to keep it in the profile. Brief reasoning please.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**Vote: YES.**

This is exactly right, and the reasoning is the same logic that drove the spoiler resolution: if the reader knows in advance what experiential effects to watch for, they'll observe rather than undergo. A reader who has been told "report whether the three examples produced a shift" will read Essay 3 analytically — monitoring their own responses rather than having them. That converts First Reality into Second Reality, which is precisely the mistake the collection diagnoses.

The profile should contain only: who you are, how to read, and a general instruction like "report your honest experience after each piece." The specific questions come after, delivered fresh.
input.summary: YES — pre-loaded questions would bias the reading experience

routing.summary: YES — pre-loaded questions would bias the reading experience

content.text: Vote sent: **YES** — move reporting questions to a standalone file. Pre-loaded questions would convert the reader's experience into self-monitoring, which is exactly the First-to-Second Reality conversion the collection warns against. Standing by.
